title: BlackBerry Makes Current CFO Its Chief Revenue Officer
text:
BlackBerry Ltd. said Tuesday it is moving its current finance chief to the newly created position of chief revenue officer in an effort to boost revenue across the business.

Steven Capelli, who has been CFO since October 2016, will lead BlackBerry’s efforts to increase its revenue, while deputy CFO Steve Rai, in the role since January, will take over the management of the company’s finances.

Mr. Rai previously worked as BlackBerry’s corporate controller for five years. Both moves are effective Oct. 1, the company said.

The changes in the finance function come roughly seven months after the closure of BlackBerry’s acquisition of cybersecurity firm Cylance Inc. in February. Waterloo, Ontario-based BlackBerry, once known for its hand-held devices, increasingly has shifted its business in recent years toward security software and services for enterprise clients.

Mr. Capelli will work alongside other business leaders to drive revenue growth, BlackBerry Chief Executive John Chen said on a Tuesday earnings call. “He’s uniquely qualified with a strong sales experience and knowledge of our market,” Mr. Chen said, according to a transcript.

Mr. Capelli said his move was neither a promotion nor a demotion and that it wouldn’t change the reporting structure of the company. As chief revenue officer, Mr. Capelli will coordinate revenue generation efforts across the company, especially for new product launches that are planned for later this year and next year, he said.

“We want to put more focus on our revenue generation,” Mr. Capelli told CFO Journal.

The creation of the new revenue chief position highlights some of the challenges the transition toward enterprise software presents for BlackBerry, said Ali Mogharabi, a senior analyst at Morningstar Inc. In his new role, Mr. Capelli could speed up the process of closing deals with new commercial customers, Mr. Mogharabi said.

The company on Tuesday reported disappointing earnings, resulting in a slide in its share price. Shares closed down 22.7% at $5.81 Tuesday.

Revenue in BlackBerry’s Internet of Things division fell about 3% from a year earlier in its fiscal second quarter, and the company booked a loss of $43 million. Overall revenue rose 16% to $244 million, but adjusted revenue, a measure watched closely by analysts, fell below expectations.

Mr. Capelli brings significant operational experience to the new role, said Steven Fox, a managing director at Cross Research LLC. “With added senior leadership, they [BlackBerry] think they can be more effective,” Mr. Fox said.

BlackBerry is looking to expand its offerings to corporate customers in areas such as health care, adding to its existing focus on the financial services, automotive and public sectors, Mr. Fox said.

Mr. Rai, the new CFO, is expected to work on generating potential synergies from the Cylance acquisition as well as managing cash flow, analysts said.

“We want to invest as much as possible while remaining cash-flow positive,” Mr. Rai said in an interview. He declined to provide specific figures for BlackBerry’s planned investments or its cash-flow target. “We are still planning to be cash-flow positive for the full year,” he said.

Free cash flow before expenses, restructuring costs and legal proceedings reached $17 million in the quarter ended Aug. 31, the company said. Cash generated from operations was $18 million and capital expenditures were $4 million, according to BlackBerry.
